questions.prompt: Which function is used to open a file in C?
questions.explanation: fopen() is the standard library function used to open files in C.

questions.prompt: What does the file mode "w" do when opening a file?
options: Opens for writing only if exists
questions.explanation: Mode "w" opens a file for writing, creating it if it doesn't exist and truncating it if it does.

questions.prompt: You must always call fclose() after opening a file with fopen().
questions.explanation: fclose() should always be called to flush buffers, release resources, and ensure data is written properly.

questions.prompt: What does fopen() return if the file cannot be opened?
questions.explanation: fopen() returns NULL if it cannot open the file. Always check for NULL after fopen().

questions.prompt: What is the difference between "r" and "r+" modes?
questions.explanation: "r" is read-only, while "r+" opens for both reading and writing. Both require the file to exist.

title: File I/O Quiz 2: Reading and Writing

questions.prompt: Which function reads a line of text from a file?
questions.explanation: fgets() reads a line (up to newline or buffer size) from a file. It's the safest way to read lines.

questions.prompt: fgets() includes the newline character in the string it reads.
questions.explanation: fgets() includes the newline (if there's room in the buffer) and always null-terminates the string.

questions.prompt: What is the return value of fgetc() when end of file is reached?
questions.explanation: fgetc() returns EOF (typically -1) when end of file is reached or an error occurs.

questions.prompt: Why does fgetc() return int instead of char?
options: To distinguish EOF from valid characters
questions.explanation: fgetc() returns int to distinguish EOF (-1) from the valid character 0xFF (255 as unsigned char).

questions.prompt: Which function writes formatted data to a file?
questions.explanation: fprintf() writes formatted data to a file, similar to printf() but with a file stream argument.

title: File I/O Quiz 3: Binary and Positioning

questions.prompt: What does the "b" in "rb" mode indicate?
questions.explanation: "b" indicates binary mode, which disables newline translation. Required for non-text files.

questions.prompt: What function is used to move the file position indicator?
questions.explanation: fseek() moves the file position indicator to a specified location in the file.

questions.prompt: What does SEEK_END mean in fseek()?
options: Position relative to end of file
questions.explanation: SEEK_END means the offset is relative to the end of the file. Often used with offset 0 to go to EOF.

questions.prompt: fread() and fwrite() work with binary data.
questions.explanation: fread() and fwrite() transfer raw bytes without interpretation, making them ideal for binary I/O.
ftell() returns the current position in the file (offset from the beginning).
